If I am following you correctly, the calculations you present pertain to the Coriolis effect – which as we can see from looking at maps of air currents and ocean currents on Earth definitely impact direction of flow, at least within the atmosphere and oceans. When considering how different ‘fluids’ in the Earth, like air, water, and for that matter mantle rock, will be affected by Earth’s rotation on its axis and revolution around the Sun it is important to take into account the viscosity of each fluid (its resistance to flow). Although viscosity of fluids is sensitive to both temperature and pressure, one can make broad comparisons between air (on the order of 10^(-5) N s/m2), (where N s/m2 is Newton seconds per meter squared) water (on the order of 10^(-3) N s/m2) and mantle rock (for the upper mantle, which is estimated to be on the order of 10^(20) N s/m2, and is which is considered relatively ‘weak’ compared to the lower mantle, – which is estimated to be on the order of 10^(23) N s/m2). Because the mantle, as a fluid, is so stiff, relative to air and water, it moves over an immense time scale compared to air and water. For this reason, it’s flow is much, much, much less affected by the Coriolis effect. Interestingly enough, though, there is a fluid deeper in the Earth than the mantle, whose flow is affected by the Coriolis effect – the outer core, which is comprised primarily of liquid iron and nickel. Computer models of convection in the outer core indicate that the Coriolus effect is significant there. So thanks to the stabilizing factor of its high viscosity, I think the Earth’s mantle will do ok without psychiatric care!
